Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: The Design and Study of Systems for Making Solar Hydrogen
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the National Science Foundation and involves a four-way collaboration between Professors David McCamant and Richard Eisenberg of the University of Rochester, and Michael Detty and David Watson of the University at Buffalo. The goal of the research is to develop a new fundamental understanding of chemical systems that can produce hydrogen by splitting water molecules into hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) gases using solar energy. For the capture and storage of solar energy, water splitting is the ideal reaction. The recombination of H2 and O2 to produce water is a convenient and clean source of energy upon demand. This research project involves making new molecules to facilitate the water splitting reaction in the Eisenberg lab, making new dye molecules to absorb visible light from the sun in the Detty lab, studying the fast photochemical reactions that occur after those molecules absorb light in the McCamant lab, and making new nanoparticle semiconductor systems as scaffolds for solar hydrogen production in the Watson lab. Each of the investigators brings to the collaborative research different perspectives and skills that are leading to a significant new understanding of a fundamentally challenging problem in solar energy conversion. In outreach efforts, the scientists supported by this grant are working with local elementary schools in Rochester and Buffalo, New York, to develop energy-related science modules that can inspire the next generation of scientists.

This research, funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF, consists of the design and study of systems for the light-driven generation of H2 from aqueous protons, and associated photochemical and photophysical investigations to fully understand this transformation. The reaction corresponds to the reductive side of water splitting, 2H+ + 2e- -> H2, which is the key reaction in artificial photosynthesis and the conversion of light into stored chemical potential energy. While seemingly simple, the detailed mechanism of the light-driven generation of H2 is complex, particularly in an integrated system. In this project, the researchers focus on three specific research goals: the synthesis and characterization of new chromophores; the design and development of new catalysts containing common metal ions that are effective in photochemical systems for light-driven proton reduction in aqueous media; and the construction of new integrated proton reduction systems based on semiconductor materials such as SrTiO3, as structural scaffolds and on photocathode materials such as CuAlO2, to eliminate the need for chemical sources of electrons for proton reduction. Each of these areas are being explored with cutting-edge femtosecond time-resolved spectroscopy capable of probing dynamics involving initial light-driven events, longer duration transient absorption methods to follow later electron transfers and steady-state methods that can establish mechanisms of catalysis, molecular and interfacial structures, and long-term system stability. The scientists supported by this grant are also working with local elementary schools in Rochester and Buffalo, New York, to develop energy related science modules that can inspire the next generation of scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Hydrogen is a highly attractive fuel, as it can be reacted with oxygen in fuel cells or combusted, with high specific energy of combustion, to yield only water as a byproduct. Photocatalytic evolution of hydrogen from water, in which systems absorb sunlight and then reduce water to hydrogen, holds promise as a carbon-neutral approach to producing hydrogen. This collaborative project involved research on the fundamental science underpinning the photocatalytic reduction of protons to hydrogen by systems comprised of molecular dyes interfaced with metal oxide semiconductors and/or molecular catalysts. Research at the University at Buffalo, as part of the broader collaborative effort, proceeded primarily on three fronts: (1) Designing and synthesizing more durable and effective photosensitizers (light-harvesting dyes); (2) measuring, using spectroscopy, and understanding the binding and orientations of dyes on semiconductor surfaces, and also the molecular-level motions correlated with electron transfer events in hydrogen evolution; and (3) interfacing dyes with p-type semiconductors to eliminate the need for sacrificial electron donors (essentially fuels that are irreversibly consumed) during photocatalysis. Key outcomes are as follows.

Design and synthesis of new dyes. A new class of dyes, “rhodaceins,” was designed and synthesized. These dyes contain a central light-absorption core and are asymmetrically functionalized at the periphery. Asymmetric functionalization enables fine-tuning of light-harvesting properties for overlap with the solar spectrum. By incorporating heavy chalcogen atoms (S, Se, Te) into the light-absorbing core of these dyes, we further red-shifted absorption spectra of dyes and controlled the pathways and time scales on which they dissipate energy after absorbing light. Understanding and controlling such factors informs the design and selection of dyes for photocatalysis systems.

Binding and orientations of dyes on surfaces. Knowledge of the chemical binding between light-absorbing dyes and semiconductor surfaces is crucial to understand, at the molecular level, the electron transfer events underpinning photocatalysis. With collaborators at Buffalo, we used doubly resonant sum-frequency generation spectroscopy to learn which specific orientations of dyes on metal oxide semiconductor surfaces promote efficient electron transfer, and, for dyes in such orientations, how they vibrate in conjunction with electron transfer. Under certain conditions, aggregation of dyes, and resulting lateral interactions between them, enhance electron transfer efficiencies. Molecules in different orientations on surfaces can transfer electrons to the semiconductor substrate, but their molecular-level motions differ and the electron transfer is usually less efficient. This information provides new fundamental insight into factors controlling the mechanism and yield of the key charge-separation step in photocatalysis, and it thus informs the design and evolution of photocatalyst systems.

New photocathodes to eliminate the need for sacrificial donors. Reduction of aqueous protons to hydrogen often requires the sacrificial (irreversible) oxidation of a different chemical component. Under these conditions, the production of hydrogen thus consumes fuel and is not sustainable or carbon-neutral. We endeavored to replace sacrificial molecular donors with p-type semiconductor photocathodes, which would enable us to perform the oxidative half of water splitting remotely and without using sacrificial molecular donors. We synthesized and characterized porous, high-surface-area thin films consisting of p-type semiconductor materials; elucidated the influence of reaction conditions and post-synthesis treatments on purity, thickness, and roughness of the films; and developed methods to attach molecular dyes to the semiconductor surface. Research on the light-initiated electron transfer and photocatalysis of these dye-semiconductor systems is ongoing.

Broader impacts: This NSF award supported the training and development of undergraduate and graduate students at the University at Buffalo and at D’Youville College. These students were trained in the methodology of research, gained hands-on skills in experimental science, acquired knowledge of fundamental concepts in inorganic, materials, and physical chemistry, and developed skills in scientific literacy and communication. The collaboration with D’Youville College yielded new partnerships within academia and provided DYC undergraduate students with access to sophisticated instrumentation and research facilities, thus expanding their training and their understanding of scientific inquiry and research methodologies. Finally, as outlined above, the research project addressed significant scientific challenges in solar energy conversion and photocatalysis, which are important to society.
